citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the licensee did not have a written, documented program of veterinary care established and
maintained under the supervision of an attending veterinarian for the two Vervets housed at this facility. During the
inspection, the licensee could not produce any program of veterinary care, written documentation of veterinary oversight
or records showing that a veterinarian has been contacted or designated to provide services for these animals. Failure to
establish and maintain a program of veterinary care places the two Vervets at risk of undetected illness, injury, and
inadequate medical treatment. Nonhuman primates require specialized preventative care, diagnosis, and treatment due to
their physiological and behavioral needs. Without veterinary involvement the health and welfare of the animals cannot be
assured. The licensee must establish a written program of veterinary care that includes the designation of an attending
veterinarian who is readily available to provide adequate veterinary care. The program must include regularly scheduled
visits, provisions for emergency care, preventative medical practices, and documentation of treatments provided.
Documented on 9-29-2025 and to be corrected by 10-1-2025.

The licensee did not have any records of acquisition or disposition for the two Vervets housed at the facility. Failure to
maintain acquisition or disposition records prevents inspectors from verifying the origin, ownership, and final disposition of
the animals, which poses a risk to animal welfare, accountability, and oversight.
Licensees must maintain complete and accurate records for each animal acquired, owned, held, leased, or disposed of
including the name and address of the person from whom the animal was obtained or to whom it was transferred, the
dates of acquisition and disposition, and a description of the animal. These records must be made available to USDA at
any time. The licensee must establish and maintain acquisition and disposition records for all covered animals in
accordance with the Animal Welfare Act.
Documented on 9-29-2025 and to be corrected by 10-1-2025.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the licensee did not have an environment enrichment program in place for two Vervets housed
at this facility. No written enrichment program was available for review and there was no evidence of documented
implementation of enrichment activities for the two Vervets. Lack of an established and maintained enrichment program
can result in stress, abnormal behavior, and diminished psychological wellbeing of the animals.
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for adequate
environment enhancement that promotes the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates. The plan must be in
accordance with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate journals or reference guides, and as
directed by the attending veterinarian. The plan must be made available to the USDA APHIS upon request.
Documented on 9-29-2025 and to be corrected by 10-1-2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Ronald Richardson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
